  • These organizational units must be assigned to plants and company codes to create a fully integrated logistics flow. For example, a plant must be assigned to a company code, and a sales organization must be assigned to a company code and have plants assigned to it from which it can sell. This assignment ensures that when you sell a product from a plant, the financial postings automatically go to the correct legal entity (company code).

Page 5: PART 2 - THE MATERIAL MASTER - THE HEART OF LOGISTICS

Chapter 4: Introduction to the Material Master

  • The Material Master is arguably the most important master data object in the SAP logistics world. It contains all the essential information required to manage a material throughout its entire lifecycle—from planning and procurement to production, sales, and controlling.

Core Concepts: Material Types, Views, and Data Hub

  • Material Master Record: A single record in the system that represents a specific material or service. Each material is assigned a unique number.
  • Material Type: A crucial classification that groups materials with similar attributes. The material type controls key system behaviors, such as:
    • Number Assignment: Whether the material number is assigned internally by the system or externally by the user.
    • Views: Which data screens (views) are available for the material.
    • Procurement Type: Whether the material is typically produced in-house, procured externally, or both.
    • Account Determination: How the material is valuated and which G/L accounts are posted to during goods movements.
    • Standard Material Types in S/4HANA:
      • ROH (Raw Materials)
      • HALB (Semi-finished Products)
      • FERT (Finished Products)
      • HAWA (Trading Goods)
      • DIEN (Services)
  • Views: The material master is organized into different data screens called "views," each corresponding to a specific business function (e.g., Sales, Purchasing, MRP, Accounting). This ensures that a sales employee doesn't have to navigate through complex production data, and vice-versa. Data is maintained at different organizational levels (e.g., basic data is at the client level, purchasing data at the plant level, sales data at the sales organization level).

The Material Master's Role Across the Value Chain

Module/Process

How the Material Master is Used

Sales & Distribution (SD)

Sales views contain data on pricing, shipping, and tax.

Materials Management (MM)

Purchasing views store vendor details, order units, and pricing conditions.

Production Planning (PP)

MRP and Work Scheduling views hold data for planning production, scheduling, and capacity.

Warehouse Management (EWM/WM)

Warehouse Management views control how the material is stored and moved within the warehouse.

Quality Management (QM)

QM view determines if a material requires quality inspection upon receipt or during production.

Finance & Controlling (FICO)

Accounting and Costing views define the material's price, valuation class, and how costs are calculated.

Page 6: Chapter 5 - How to Create a Material Master Record

  • In SAP S/4HANA, the primary way to manage material master data is through dedicated Fiori applications that provide a streamlined and intuitive user experience.

Using the SAP Fiori App "Create Material"

  • The "Create Material" (Fiori App ID: MM01) and "Change Material" (Fiori App ID: MM02) apps are the modern successors to the classic GUI transactions.
  • Key Features of the Fiori App:
  • Guided Process: The app walks you through the creation process step-by-step.
  • Clear Layout: Views are organized into clear tabs, making it easy to navigate.
  • Real-time Validation: The system provides immediate feedback on data entry errors.

Step-by-Step Walkthrough: Creating a Raw Material

  • Scenario: We need to create a new raw material, a steel plate, that our company will purchase from an external supplier to manufacture bicycle frames.
  1. Launch the App: Open the Fiori Launchpad and click on the Create Material tile.
  2. Initial Screen:
    • Material: Leave blank if using internal number assignment. Our system is configured for this.
    • Industry sector: Select M - Mechanical engineering. This controls the fields that appear later.
    • Material Type: Select ROH - Raw materials.
    • Click Enter or the Continue button.
  3. Select Views: A pop-up appears. Select the views necessary for a purchased raw material:
    • Basic Data 1 & 2
    • Purchasing
    • General Plant Data / Storage 1 & 2
    • Accounting 1 & 2
    • Costing 1 & 2
    • Click Continue.
  4. Organizational Levels: Specify the levels at which the views will be created.
    • Plant: Enter your manufacturing plant (e.g., 1010).
    • Storage Location: Enter the raw materials storage location (e.g., 101A).
    • Click Continue.
  5. Populate the Views: Fill in the data for each view (tab).
    • Basic Data 1:
      • Description: Steel Plate 5mm
      • Base Unit of Measure: KG
      • Material Group: STEEL (Raw Steel Products)
    • Purchasing:
      • Purchasing Group: 001 (Raw Material Purchasing)
      • Order Unit: TON (Often purchased in larger quantities)
    • General Plant Data / Storage 1:
      • Unit of Issue: KG
    • Accounting 1:
      • Valuation Class: 3000 (Raw Materials)
      • Price control: V (Moving average price)
      • Moving Price: Enter an estimated initial price (e.g., 2.50 USD).
  6. Save the Material: Click the Save button. The system will confirm with a message at the bottom of the screen: "Material [Number] created." Take note of this number!

Page 7: Step-by-Step Walkthrough: Creating a Finished Good

  • Scenario: Now, we'll create the finished product that we manufacture and sell: a premium bicycle frame.
  1. Launch the App: Open the Create Material Fiori app.
  2. Initial Screen:
    • Industry sector: M - Mechanical engineering
    • Material Type: FERT - Finished products
  3. Select Views: For a finished good that is produced in-house and sold, select a broader range of views:
    • Basic Data 1 & 2
    • Sales: Sales Org. 1 & 2
    • Sales: General/Plant
    • MRP 1, 2, 3, 4
    • Work Scheduling
    • General Plant Data / Storage 1 & 2
    • Accounting 1 & 2
    • Costing 1 & 2
  4. Organizational Levels:
    • Plant: 1010
    • Storage Location: 101F (Finished Goods)
    • Sales Organization: 1010
    • Distribution Channel: 10 (Wholesale)
  5. Populate the Views:
    • Basic Data 1:
      • Description: Premium Bicycle Frame - Large
      • Base Unit of Measure: EA (Each)
      • Material Group: FGBIKE (Finished Bicycles/Frames)
      • Division: 01 (Bicycles)
    • Sales: Sales Org. 1:
      • Delivering Plant: 1010
      • Tax classification: 1 (for all relevant countries)
    • Sales: General/Plant:
      • Availability Check: 01 (Daily requirements)
      • Transportation Group: 0001 (On pallets)
      • Loading Group: 0001 (Crane)
    • MRP 1:
      • MRP Type: PD (MRP)
      • MRP Controller: 001 (Planner for Finished Goods)
      • Lot size: EX (Lot-for-lot)
    • Work Scheduling:
      • Production scheduler: 001 (Shop Floor Supervisor)
    • Accounting 1:
      • Valuation Class: 7920 (Finished Goods)
      • Price control: S (Standard price)
      • Standard Price: Enter the calculated standard cost (e.g., 150.00 USD).
  6. Save the Material: Click the Save button and note the new material number.

Page 8: Chapter 6 - Key Groupings and Classifications

  • Several fields on the material master are not just informational; they are powerful configuration objects that drive system behavior, organization, and reporting. These are defined in customizing and then assigned to materials.

Industry Sector

  • Concept: The Industry Sector is one of the first fields you fill out when creating a material (MM01 or the "Create Material" Fiori app). Its primary function is to control which screens and fields are displayed during material master maintenance. For example, a material for the "Chemicals" industry sector might have different fields available than one for "Mechanical Engineering."
  • Use Case: This ensures that users are only presented with fields relevant to their industry, simplifying data entry and reducing errors.
  • Customizing Point (Consultant):
    • Path: SPRO -> Logistics - General -> Material Master -> Field Selection -> Assign Fields to Field Selection Groups.
    • Here, you can also define new industry sectors via Define Industry Sectors and Industry-Sector-Specific Field Selection. In this step, you link an industry sector to a "Field Reference." The Field Reference key (e.g., M for Mechanical Engineering) is what actually controls the field statuses (Hide, Display, Required, Optional).
  • Example:
  • In the provided documents, the industry sector M (Constructions mécaniques) is linked to field reference M. This means any material created with industry sector M will have its field visibility and requirement status controlled by the settings assigned to field reference M.

Material Group

  • Concept: A Material Group is a way to group together materials with similar attributes or characteristics. It is a broader grouping than the material type.
  • Use Case: Material Groups are essential for reporting and analytics. You can analyze purchasing spend by material group, structure sales reports, or use them in strategic sourcing. When a material is created, the material group can automatically populate the Valuation Class in the accounting view if configured, streamlining data entry.
  • Customizing Point (Consultant):
    • Path: SPRO -> Logistics - General -> Material Master -> Settings for Key Fields -> Define Material Groups.
    • This is a simple table where you define a key (up to 9 alphanumeric characters) and a description.
    • Example: You can create material groups like STEEL, ALUMINUM, PLASTICS for raw materials, and ROADBIKE, MTBBIKE for finished goods.

Page 9: Product Hierarchy

  • Concept: The Product Hierarchy is a flexible, multi-level structure used primarily in Sales and Distribution (SD) and profitability analysis (CO-PA) for pricing and reporting. It allows you to classify your products from a sales-oriented perspective. A standard hierarchy can have up to 3 levels with a total of 18 characters.
    • Level 1: e.g., 001 (Bicycles)
    • Level 2: e.g., 001001 (Road Bikes)
    • Level 3: e.g., 001001001 (Carbon Frame Road Bikes)
  • Use Case:
    • Pricing: You can create pricing conditions at any level of the hierarchy. For instance, you could offer a 10% discount on all "Road Bikes" (001001).
    • Reporting: It provides a powerful and structured way to analyze sales figures. You can easily see your total revenue for "Bicycles," then drill down to "Road Bikes," and further to "Carbon Frame" models.
  • Customizing Point (Consultant):
    • Path: SPRO -> Logistics - General -> Material Master -> Settings for Key Fields -> Data Relevant to Sales and Distribution -> Define Product Hierarchies.
    • Transaction Code: V/76
    • In this transaction, you define the structure of the hierarchy—each node, its level, and its description.
    • Example: As shown in the source document, you would create an entry for level 1 001 (Machines), then level 2 00100001 (Pumps), and so on.

Profit Center (The S/4HANA Approach to Internal Reporting)

  • Concept: While the source documents mention "Secteur d'activité" (Business Area), in SAP S/4HANA, the Profit Center is the primary organizational unit for internal management accounting (Controlling). A Profit Center represents a sub-area of a company for which a separate profit and loss result can be determined.
  • Use Case: Profit Centers are used to analyze the profitability of different product lines, business units, or geographical locations. For every material, you assign a Profit Center in the General Plant Data / Storage 2 or Sales: General/Plant view. When goods are sold or moved, the revenue and costs are automatically posted to the assigned profit center.
  • Integration: In S/4HANA's Universal Journal (table ACDOCA), the Profit Center is a key field, making real-time profitability analysis a standard feature. While Business Areas still exist for backward compatibility, new implementations should focus on a robust Profit Center structure.
  • Customizing Point (Consultant):
    • Profit Centers are master data themselves, created via Fiori App "Manage Profit Centers."
    • The assignment to materials is done directly in the material master. The determination can be automated based on other factors like the Material Group.

Page 10: PART 3 - ADVANCED AND RELATED MASTER DATA OBJECTS

Chapter 7: Managing Products with Batch Management

  • Batch Management is a critical functionality for industries where traceability, shelf life, or specific product characteristics are important, such as pharmaceuticals, chemicals, and food & beverage.

What is a Batch and Why Use It?

  • A batch is a specific quantity of a material that was produced or procured together and shares the same characteristics. Each batch is given a unique number, allowing it to be tracked throughout its lifecycle.
  • Key reasons to use Batch Management:
  • Traceability: In case of a product recall, you can quickly identify which customers received products from a specific faulty batch.
  • Quality Management: Track quality inspection results for each batch.
  • Status Management: Control whether a batch can be used (e.g., "Unrestricted" vs. "Restricted/Blocked"). A new batch might be in "Restricted" status until quality checks are complete.
  • Characteristic Management: Store specific values for a batch, such as potency, color shade, or ingredient concentration.

Configuration: Setting the Batch Level

  • This fundamental setting determines the scope of uniqueness for a batch number. It is a critical decision that cannot be changed easily once transactional data exists.
  • Concept: You must decide if a batch number should be unique at the following levels:
    1. Client Level: Batch number BATCH-001 is unique across the entire system. It can only be assigned to one material number.
    2. Material Level: Batch number BATCH-001 is unique for a specific material. The same batch number can be used for different materials.
    3. Plant Level: Batch number BATCH-001 is unique for a material within a specific plant. The same material in a different plant can have the same batch number. This is the SAP standard and most common setting.
  • Customizing Point (Consultant):
    • Transaction Code: OMCE
    • Path: SPRO -> Logistics - General -> Batch Management -> Specify Batch Level and Activate Status Management.
    • In this screen, you select the desired level.

Activating Batch Status Management

  • Concept: This setting enables the use of statuses to control the usability of a batch. By default, a batch has two statuses:
    • Unrestricted: The batch is available for all business processes (sales, production, etc.).
    • Restricted: The batch is blocked from most movements. This is useful for stock that is under quality inspection, on hold, or expired.
  • Customizing Point (Consultant):
    • Transaction Code: OMCE
    • Path: SPRO -> Logistics - General -> Batch Management -> Specify Batch Level and Activate Status Management.
    • Check the "Batch status management active" box. Once activated at the client level, you can then specify which plants will use it.

Page 11: Automatic Batch Creation During Goods Movements

  • Manually creating a batch number for every single goods receipt can be tedious and prone to error. SAP allows you to configure the system to create batch numbers automatically during specific goods movements.
  • Concept: You can configure each MM Movement Type to control how new batches are created. This is especially useful for goods receipts from production or external procurement (e.g., Movement Type 101).
  • Configuration Options per Movement Type:
    • A - Automatic / Manual without check: The system proposes a new batch number, but the user can overwrite it. No check is performed.
    • B - Automatic / Manual with check: The system proposes a new batch number. If the user enters one manually, the system checks if it is within the external number range.
    • C - Automatic only / No manual creation: The system must assign the batch number automatically. The user cannot enter one. This is the most controlled option.
    • D - Manual only / No automatic creation: The user must always enter the batch number manually. The system will not propose one.
  • Customizing Point (Consultant):
    • Path: SPRO -> Logistics - General -> Batch Management -> Creation of New Batches -> Define Batch Creation for Goods Movements.
    • In this activity, you select a Movement Type (e.g., 101 for Goods Receipt) and set the desired automatic creation option.
  • Practical Exercise:
  1. Requirement: For all goods receipts from purchase orders (Movement Type 101), the business wants to enforce that the system always creates the batch number to ensure consistency. Manual entry should be forbidden.
  2. Configuration Step: Go to the customizing path above. Find Movement Type 101. Set the "New Batch" indicator to C - automatically/no new manual creation.
  3. Prerequisite: For automatic creation to work, internal number range 01 for the object BATCH_CLT must be maintained.
  4. Result: Now, when a user posts a goods receipt for a batch-managed material using transaction MIGO (or the Fiori app "Post Goods Receipt"), the batch number field will be grayed out, and the system will assign the next available number from the internal number range upon posting.

Page 12: Chapter 8 - The Business Partner (BP) Approach

  • A major architectural change in SAP S/4HANA is the mandatory use of the Business Partner (BP) object to manage customers and vendors. The old, separate transactions (XD01, XK01) are obsolete.

From Legacy to Modern: The End of Separate Customers/Vendors

  • In legacy SAP ERP, customer master data and vendor master data were separate objects created with different transactions. This led to data redundancy. If a company was both a customer and a vendor, you had to create two separate master records with much of the same information (name, address, bank details).
  • The Business Partner model solves this by creating a single, unified master data record for any person or organization that you do business with.
  • General Data: Information like name, address, and bank details is stored at the central BP level. This data is created only once.
  • Roles: Specific functionalities are added to the BP by assigning Roles. A single BP can have multiple roles.
    • FI Customer Role: Contains company-code-specific data for accounting (e.g., reconciliation account).
    • Customer Role: Contains sales-area-specific data for sales order processing (e.g., shipping conditions, pricing).
    • FI Vendor Role: Contains company-code-specific data for accounts payable.
    • Supplier Role: Contains purchasing-organization-specific data for procurement (e.g., order currency, payment terms).

Creating a Business Partner for Procurement and Sales

  • Scenario: We need to create a new Business Partner, "Global Bike Components," which is both a supplier from whom we buy steel plates and a customer to whom we sometimes sell excess parts.
  • How-To: Using the "Manage Business Partner Master Data" Fiori App
  1. Launch the App: Open the Fiori Launchpad and search for the app Manage Business Partner Master Data. Click Create -> Organization.
  2. Create BP (General Data):
    • In the initial screen, select a BP Grouping which controls the number range.
    • Enter the company name: Global Bike Components.
    • Enter address information, communication details (phone, email), and bank details. This is the central, role-independent data.
    • Click Save. The system creates the BP in the "General" role and assigns a BP number.
  3. Extend to Supplier Role:
    • Open the newly created BP in "Change" mode.
    • In the "Roles" section, add the role FLVN00 - FI Vendor.
    • A new "Company Code" segment will appear. Click "Create."
    • Enter your Company Code (e.g., 1010), set the Reconciliation Account, and other financial data.
    • Save the changes.
    • Now, add the role FLVN01 - Supplier.
    • A new "Purchasing" segment will appear. Click "Create."
    • Enter your Purchasing Organization (e.g., 1010), set the Order Currency, Payment Terms, and other procurement-related data.
    • Save the changes.
  4. Extend to Customer Role:
    • In the same BP record, add the role FLCU00 - FI Customer.
    • In the new "Company Code" segment for the customer role, enter the relevant financial data.
    • Save the changes.
    • Add the role FLCU01 - Customer.
    • In the new "Sales and Distribution" segment, enter your Sales Area (Sales Org/Dist. Channel/Division), and set the Shipping Conditions, Pricing Procedure, etc.
    • Save the changes.
  • Result: You now have a single Business Partner number (900XXXXX) that is fully functional as both a customer and a supplier across all relevant organizational levels. This eliminates data redundancy and simplifies master data maintenance.

Page 13: Chapter 9 - Essential Production and Planning Master Data

  • For companies that manufacture products, a set of production-specific master data is required to define how a product is made.

Bill of Materials (BOM)

  • Concept: A Bill of Materials is a structured list of all the components, raw materials, and assemblies required to produce a finished or semi-finished product. It's essentially the recipe for a product.
  • Use Case:
    • MRP: During the planning run, the system explodes the BOM to determine the required quantities of all components.
    • Production: When a production order is created, the BOM is copied to the order to create a list of components to be issued from stock.
    • Costing: The BOM is used to calculate the material cost of a finished product.
  • Fiori App: "Manage Bill of Materials"

Work Center

  • Concept: A Work Center is a master data object that represents a specific location or resource in a plant where a production operation is performed. It can be a machine, a group of machines, a production line, or a group of people (e.g., an assembly station).
  • Use Case:
    • Scheduling: The work center contains formulas and capacity data used to calculate the duration of production operations.
    • Capacity Planning: Used to determine if you have enough capacity to meet production demands.
    • Costing: The work center is linked to cost centers and activity types (e.g., machine hours, labor hours) to calculate the production costs.
  • Fiori App: "Manage Work Center"

Routing

  • Concept: A Routing is a sequence of operations that must be performed at various work centers to produce a material. It details the "how-to" steps of manufacturing.
  • Use Case:
    • The routing lists the operations in order, the work center where each operation is done, and the standard times (setup, machine, labor) required for each step.
    • It is the primary input for production order scheduling and costing.
  • Fiori App: "Manage Routings"

Production Version: The Key to S/4HANA Manufacturing

  • Concept: The Production Version is a crucial master data object in S/4HANA that links a product's BOM to its Routing. It determines exactly which BOM and which routing should be used to produce a material. A material can have multiple production versions (e.g., for different production lines or alternative components).
  • Mandatory in S/4HANA: Unlike in legacy ERP where it was optional in some scenarios, the Production Version is mandatory for all in-house production processes in S/4HANA (MRP, production order creation).
  • Creation: Production Versions are maintained directly within the material master record using the Fiori app "Manage Product Master Data" or within the "Manage Production Versions" app.
  • Example Flow:
  • To produce our Premium Bicycle Frame (FG-2001):
  1. A BOM is created listing the components: Steel Plate 5mm (RM-1001), welding wire, paint, etc.
  2. Work Centers are defined: WC-WELD (Welding Station), WC-PAINT (Paint Booth), WC-ASSY (Final Assembly).
  3. A Routing is created with three operations:
    • Op 10: Weld Frame (at WC-WELD)
    • Op 20: Paint Frame (at WC-PAINT)
    • Op 30: Final Inspection (at WC-ASSY)
  4. A Production Version (PV01) is created for material FG-2001, linking the BOM and the Routing together. This version is then used by MRP and for creating production orders.

Page 14: PART 4 - A CONSULTANT'S VIEW - CUSTOMIZING MASTER DATA

  • This section provides an overview of how the master data objects discussed are configured in the system. This is typically the responsibility of functional consultants.

Using the Implementation Guide (SPRO) and CBC

  • On-Premise/Private Cloud: The primary tool is the SAP Implementation Guide (IMG), accessed with T-code SPRO. It provides a hierarchical tree of all configuration activities.
  • Public Cloud: Configuration is managed through Central Business Configuration (CBC) and the "Manage Your Solution" Fiori app. CBC is a guided, scope-item-based approach to configuring the system. While the tools differ, the underlying business concepts are the same.

Configuring Field Selection by Industry Sector

  • As mentioned in Chapter 6, the Industry Sector is a powerful tool for tailoring the material master screen.
  • How-To: Adjust Field Status
  1. Path: SPRO -> Logistics - General -> Material Master -> Field Selection.
  2. Define Field Reference: First, ensure you have a Field Reference key for your industry sector (e.g., M for Mechanical Engineering).
  3. Assign Fields: Go to Assign Fields to Field Selection Groups. Here, SAP groups hundreds of material master fields into logical "Field Selection Groups." You find the field you want to change and note its group number.
  4. Maintain Field Status: Go to Maintain Field Selection for Data Screens. You will see a list of Field References. Double-click the one linked to your industry sector (e.g., M).
  5. Set Status: You will see the list of Field Selection Groups. Find the group containing your field and set the status for that group to one of the following:
    • Hide (-): The field will not be visible.
    • Display (.): The field is visible but cannot be edited.
    • Required Entry (+): The user must fill in this field to save the material.
    • Optional Entry ( 😞 The field is visible and can be filled in if needed (standard behavior).
  • Priority Logic: The system uses a priority logic to determine the final status of a field if it has conflicting settings (e.g., from material type and industry sector). The logic is: Hide > Display > Required > Optional. If any setting says "Hide," the field will be hidden, regardless of other settings.

Defining Number Ranges for Material Types and Business Partners

  • Material Master:
    • Path: SPRO -> Logistics - General -> Material Master -> Basic Settings -> Material Types -> Define Number Ranges for Each Material Type.
    • Here, you define number range intervals (e.g., from 100000 to 199999).
    • Then, you assign these intervals to groups.
    • Finally, in the Define Attributes of Material Types step, you assign a group to each material type (FERT, ROH, etc.). This links the material type to its specific number range.
  • Business Partner:
    • Path: SPRO -> Cross-Application Components -> SAP Business Partner -> Business Partner -> Basic Settings -> Number Ranges and Groupings.
    • Define Number Ranges: Create the intervals.
    • Define Groupings and Assign Number Ranges: Create a "Grouping" (e.g., Z001 for Domestic Suppliers) and assign the number range interval to it. This grouping is what the user selects when creating a new BP in the Fiori app.

Page 15: PART 5 - THE INTEGRATED MASTER DATA TEST PLAN

Introduction to the Test Plan

  • This test plan provides a series of structured, end-to-end scenarios to create, validate, and use the master data discussed in this guide. The goal is to ensure that the data is not only created correctly but also functions as expected in integrated business processes.
  • Target Audience:
  • Scenarios 1: Primarily for Consultants and Key Users to validate system configuration.
  • Scenarios 2-3: Primarily for Key Users and Master Data Stewards to practice data creation.
  • Scenarios 4-5: Primarily for End Users (e.g., Purchasers, Sales Reps) and for UAT (User Acceptance Testing) to verify the entire process flow.
  • Prerequisites:
  • The core organizational structure (Company Code 1010, Plant 1010, Sales Org 1010, etc.) is configured.
  • Users have the necessary authorizations for the Fiori apps and transactions mentioned.

Scenario 1: Foundational Configuration Validation (Consultant)

Test Step

Action

Expected Result

Pass/Fail

1.1

Go to T-Code OMCE.

The screen to set the Batch Level and activate Status Management appears.

 

1.2

Verify that the Batch Level is set to "Batch unique at plant level."

The radio button for "Batch unique at plant/material" is selected.

 

1.3

Verify that Batch Status Management is active.

The checkbox "Batch status management active" is checked.

 

1.4

Navigate to SPRO -> Logistics - General -> Batch Management -> Creation of New Batches -> Define Batch Creation for Goods Movements.

The activity screen opens, showing a list of movement types.

 

1.5

Check the entry for Movement Type 101.

The "New Batch" indicator is set to 'C' (automatically/no new manual creation).

 

1.6

Go to T-Code V/76.

The Product Hierarchy maintenance screen appears.

 

1.7

Verify that a Level 1 hierarchy node for Bicycles exists.

An entry exists for Level 1, e.g., Code BICYCLE, Description All Bicycles.

 

1.8

Navigate to SPRO -> Logistics - General -> Material Master -> Settings for Key Fields -> Define Material Groups.

The Material Group overview screen appears.

 

1.9

Verify that material group STEEL exists.

An entry for STEEL with description "Raw Steel Products" is present.

 

Page 16: Scenario 2: Creating an End-to-End Raw Material (Key User)

  • Objective: Create a new raw material, "Aluminum Tube," and verify all relevant views and fields are populated correctly.

Test Step

Action

Data to Enter / Check

Expected Result

Pass/Fail

2.1

Launch Fiori App "Create Material".

Material: (blank), Industry Sector: M, Material Type: ROH

The 'Select View(s)' pop-up appears.

 

2.2

Select Views.

Basic Data, Purchasing, General Plant/Storage, Accounting, Costing.

The 'Organizational Levels' pop-up appears.

 

2.3

Define Org. Levels.

Plant: 1010, SLoc: 101A

The 'Basic Data 1' tab is displayed.

 

2.4

Populate Basic Data.

Description: Aluminum Tube 3cm, Base UoM: M (Meter), Material Group: ALUMINUM

Data is accepted.

 

2.5

Populate Purchasing View.

Purchasing Group: 001

Data is accepted.

 

2.6

Populate Accounting 1 View.

Valuation Class: 3001 (Aluminum), Price Control: V, Moving Price: 5.50

Data is accepted.

 

2.7

Save the Material.

Click the 'Save' button.

The system returns a success message: "Material XXXXX created". Note the number.

 

2.8

Verify Creation.

Launch "Display Material" app and enter the new material number.

All populated data is displayed correctly across the selected views.

 

Scenario 3: Creating a Batch-Managed Finished Good (Key User)

  • Objective: Create a new finished good, "Touring Bicycle," which will be batch-managed.

Test Step

Action

Data to Enter / Check

Expected Result

Pass/Fail

3.1

Launch Fiori App "Create Material".

Material: (blank), Industry Sector: M, Material Type: FERT

The 'Select View(s)' pop-up appears.

 

3.2

Select Views.

Basic Data, Sales, MRP, Work Scheduling, General Plant/Storage, Accounting, Costing.

The 'Organizational Levels' pop-up appears.

 

3.3

Define Org. Levels.

Plant: 1010, SLoc: 101F, Sales Org: 1010, Distr. Channel: 10

The 'Basic Data 1' tab is displayed.

 

3.4

Populate Basic Data.

Description: Touring Bicycle - Red, Base UoM: EA, Product Hierarchy: BICYCLE-TOUR

Data is accepted.

 

3.5

Populate Sales: General/Plant View.

Availability Check: 01

Data is accepted.

 

3.6

Activate Batch Management.

In the General Plant Data / Storage 1 view, check the "Batch Management" checkbox.

The checkbox is selected. This is the key step.

 

3.7

Populate Accounting 1 View.

Valuation Class: 7920, Price Control: S, Standard Price: 350.00

Data is accepted.

 

3.8

Save the Material.

Click the 'Save' button.

The system returns a success message: "Material YYYYY created". Note the number.

 

3.9

Verify Creation.

Launch "Display Material" app and enter the new material number. Check the Plant/Storage 1 view.

The "Batch Management" indicator is correctly set.

 

Page 17: Scenario 4: End-to-End Procure-to-Pay (P2P) Cycle (End User)

  • Objective: Use the newly created raw material and a new supplier to test the complete procurement cycle, including the automatic batch creation for a second batch-managed raw material.
  • Prerequisite Data:
  • Material 1 (non-batch): Aluminum Tube (from Scenario 2)
  • Material 2 (batch-managed): Create a new ROH material RM-PAINT-RED for "Red Bicycle Paint," ensuring the "Batch Management" checkbox is ticked.
  • Supplier: Create a new Business Partner SUPPLIER-A with Supplier and FI Vendor roles.

Test Step

Action

Data to Enter / Check

Expected Result

Pass/Fail

4.1

Create Purchase Requisition (PR)

Fiori App "Manage Purchase Requisitions". Add both Aluminum Tube (100 M) and RM-PAINT-RED (50 L).

PR is created successfully.

 

4.2

Create Purchase Order (PO)

Fiori App "Manage Purchase Orders". Create a PO referencing the PR for supplier SUPPLIER-A.

PO is created successfully.

 

4.3

Post Goods Receipt (GR)

Fiori App "Post Goods Receipt for Purchase Order". Enter the PO number.

The two material line items appear.

 

4.4

Check Batch Field for RM-PAINT-RED.

On the line item for RM-PAINT-RED, the "Batch" field should be grayed out and not editable.

Confirms that the customizing for MVT 101 (indicator 'C') is working as expected.

 

4.5

Post the GR.

Check the "Item OK" box for both lines and click Post.

The material document is posted. A new batch number is automatically created and assigned to the paint.

 

4.6

Check Stock Overview

Fiori App "Stock - Single Material". Check the stock for RM-PAINT-RED.

The stock is visible in quality inspection or unrestricted use, under the newly created batch number. The batch has a "Restricted" status if QM is active.

 

4.7

Post Supplier Invoice

Fiori App "Create Supplier Invoice". Reference the PO number.

The invoice is posted, completing the financial part of the transaction.

 

Scenario 5: End-to-End Order-to-Cash (O2C) Cycle (End User)

  • Objective: Sell the newly created batch-managed finished good to a new customer.
  • Prerequisite Data:
  • Material: Touring Bicycle - Red (from Scenario 3). Assume stock exists for a specific batch, BATCH-BIKE-001.
  • Customer: Create a new Business Partner CUST-A with Customer and FI Customer roles.
  • Pricing: Maintain a price for the material using the "Manage Prices - Sales" Fiori app.

Test Step

Action

Data to Enter / Check

Expected Result

Pass/Fail

5.1

Create Sales Order

Fiori App "Create Sales Orders". Enter customer CUST-A and material Touring Bicycle - Red for a quantity of 5 EA.

The sales order is created successfully. The price is determined automatically.

 

5.2

Create Outbound Delivery

Fiori App "Manage Outbound Deliveries". Create a delivery referencing the sales order.

The delivery document is created. The system shows a picking status.

 

5.3

Perform Batch Determination in Delivery.

In the picking tab of the delivery, the system needs to know which batch to ship. Use the batch determination function or enter batch BATCH-BIKE-001 manually.

The batch is assigned to the delivery quantity.

 

5.4

Post Goods Issue (PGI)

From the outbound delivery app, click Post Goods Issue.

The stock of BATCH-BIKE-001 is reduced by 5 EA. Financial documents for COGS are posted automatically.

 

5.5

Create Customer Invoice

Fiori App "Create Billing Documents". Reference the outbound delivery.

The billing document (invoice) is created and sent to the customer. Financial documents for revenue are posted.

 

5.6

Check Document Flow

Open the sales order using the "Manage Sales Orders" app.

The document flow shows the complete chain: Sales Order -> Delivery -> Picking -> Goods Issue -> Invoice -> Accounting Docs.

entry.title: Re: SAP PS Activity Error Encountered During Period Closing
entry.content:
Hello @ggizemkaya ,

Thank you for sharing the screenshot. It is very helpful

Even if the network plan is APPROVED, each activity must have a status that allows for actual execution. Verify the status profile in BS33 to ensure activities are set to 'REL' (released) and not locked by a user status. After correcting the statuses and ensuring the COFC is clear, the CO period close can be finalised.

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: The Power of the Batch: Why Traceability is Non-Negotiable in Supply Chain 🧪📦
entry.content:
Introduction to Batch Management

Welcome to your definitive guide on Batch Management in SAP S/4HANA. This document is designed for a wide audience, from end-users performing daily tasks to functional consultants responsible for system configuration. We will journey from the fundamental concepts to the intricate details of configuration and execution across the entire logistics chain.

What is a Batch and Why is it Crucial?

In manufacturing and distribution, a batch (or lot) represents a specific quantity of material produced or procured together, sharing the same specifications and characteristics. Think of a batch of paint from a single production run, a lot of raw chemicals from one supplier delivery, or a specific harvest of organic coffee beans.

Batch Management is the process of tracking and managing these unique batches throughout the supply chain. Its importance cannot be overstated, particularly in industries like pharmaceuticals, food and beverage, chemicals, and aerospace.

Key Benefits of Batch Management

  • Full Traceability: The cornerstone of batch management. It provides the ability to perform a "where-used" analysis, tracing a finished product batch all the way back to the raw material batches used in its production (bottom-up) or tracing a raw material batch forward to all the finished products it was used in (top-down). This is critical for product recalls, quality analysis, and regulatory compliance.
  • Quality Assurance & Compliance: Batches can be linked to quality inspection results. A specific batch can be put on "Restricted" status if it fails inspection, preventing its use or sale until a final decision is made.
  • Shelf-Life and Expiration Management: For perishable goods, managing the Shelf Life Expiration Date (SLED) at the batch level is essential. This ensures that older stock is used first (FIFO/FEFO principle) and prevents the sale or use of expired products.
  • Precise Inventory Management: Instead of viewing stock as a single quantity, batch management allows you to see it as a collection of unique sub-quantities, each with its own characteristics (e.g., potency, color grade, country of origin).
  • Targeted Recalls: If a defect is found, you can recall the specific, affected batch(es) instead of issuing a costly and damaging recall of the entire product line.

Batch Management in SAP S/4HANA

While the core principles of batch management remain the same from SAP ECC, S/4HANA introduces streamlined processes, a superior user experience with SAP Fiori, and enhanced analytics. Throughout this guide, we will highlight the modern SAP S/4HANA GUI transactions and the equivalent SAP Fiori applications.

Chapter 1: Master Data – The Foundation of Batch Management

Correctly configured master data is the prerequisite for all batch management processes.

1.1 Material Master

The journey begins with the material master record. Here, you decide if a material will be managed in batches.

Activating Batch Management

To activate batch management for a material, you must set the Batch management indicator (MARA-XCHPF). This setting is typically found in the General Plant Data / Storage 1 or Purchasing view of the material master.

  • SAP GUI: Transaction MM01 (Create) / MM02 (Change)
  • SAP Fiori App: Manage Product Master Data

Critical Note: This indicator is set at the client level. Once a material is batch-managed, it is batch-managed in all plants where it exists. You cannot change this setting once stock exists for the material. You must reverse all stock postings before you can deactivate it.

Shelf Life Expiration Date (SLED) Data

For perishable items, you must maintain SLED data in the Plant Data / Stor. 1 view.

  • Total shelf life: The total lifespan of the product in days, from the date of production. For example, 365 days.
  • Min. remaining shelf life: The minimum number of days a batch must be valid upon goods receipt to be accepted. For example, 90 days. If a batch is received with only 80 days of shelf life remaining, the system will issue a warning or error message, depending on configuration.

This data is crucial for the system to automatically calculate the SLED during goods receipt and to perform availability checks.

1.2 Batch Classification

Classification is the heart of batch management, allowing you to store specific, detailed information for each batch. This is what allows you to search for batches based on characteristics like potency, color, or supplier certificate number. The system uses a standard Class Type 023 for batches.

1.2.1 Characteristics (Transaction CT04)

Characteristics are the individual data fields you want to maintain for a batch. SAP provides several standard characteristics that are automatically populated from system data. It's best practice to use these whenever possible.

Standard SAP Characteristics:

  • LOBM_VFDAT: Shelf Life Expiration Date.
  • LOBM_HSDAT: Date of Manufacture.
  • LOBM_ZUSTD: Batch Status (Unrestricted/Restricted).
  • LOBM_LVORM: Deletion Flag.
  • LOBM_VERAB: Availability Date.

Creating Custom Characteristics: You can create your own characteristics for business-specific needs. For example:

  • Z_POTENCY: Numeric, for the active ingredient percentage.
  • Z_COLOR_CODE: Character, for a specific color value.
  • Z_COUNTRY_OF_ORIGIN: Character, for the batch's origin.

When creating a characteristic, you can link it to a table field. For example, the creation date of the batch is stored in table MCHA, field ERSDA. You can create a characteristic that pulls this date automatically, making it non-editable for users.

1.2.2 Classes (Transaction CL02)

A Class is a container for characteristics. You group all relevant characteristics for a type of material into a single class.

Example: Class for a Pharmaceutical Raw Material

  • Class: CL_PHARMA_RM
  • Class Type: 023 (Batches)
  • Characteristics Assigned:
    • LOBM_VFDAT (SLED)
    • LOBM_HSDAT (Date of Manufacture)
    • Z_POTENCY
    • Z_COUNTRY_OF_ORIGIN

1.2.3 Assigning the Class to the Material Master

Finally, you must assign the batch class to the material master in the Classification view.

  • SAP GUI: Transaction MM01 / MM02
  • SAP Fiori App: Manage Product Master Data

Once assigned, every time a new batch is created for this material (e.g., during a goods receipt), the system will prompt the user to enter values for these characteristics, or it can populate them in the background.

Critical Note: Once a single batch has been created for a material, you can no longer change the class assigned in the material master. It is vital to get this right during the initial data setup.

Chapter 2: Configuration – Building the Engine

This section is for key users and consultants. It outlines the essential customizing steps required to make batch management work seamlessly. These settings are configured in the Implementation Guide (IMG).

  • SPRO Path: Logistics - General -> Batch Management

2.1 Batch Number Assignment

You can define how batch numbers are created.

  • Internal Assignment: SAP assigns a sequential number automatically. This is the most common and recommended approach.
  • External Assignment: Users manually enter the batch number, often the supplier's batch number.

The number ranges are managed using the Number Range Object BATCH_CLT.

  • SAP GUI: Transaction SNRO
  • Action: You define the number range intervals. For performance, especially in high-volume environments, it's possible to buffer the number range. Buffering means the application server fetches a block of numbers (e.g., 10) into its memory to assign them faster, avoiding a database call for every single batch creation.

It is also possible to implement a

User Exit (EXIT_SAPLV01Z_001) or a BAdI to create complex, formatted batch numbers (e.g., P-YYYYMM-NNNNN) based on business rules, as suggested by the V2... format in the source documents.

2.2 Batch Status Management

By default, a new batch has a status of "Unrestricted." You can activate Batch Status Management to allow for a second status: "Restricted."

  • SPRO Path: Batch Management -> Specify Batch Level and Activate Status Management

A restricted batch cannot be used for most logistic movements (e.g., goods issue to a customer, consumption in production), providing a powerful control mechanism. This status is fully integrated with the Quality Management (QM) module, where a "Reject" usage decision can automatically set the batch status to "Restricted."

2.3 Batch Determination (The Condition Technique)

This is the most powerful and complex part of batch management configuration. Batch determination automatically finds and selects batches during logistical processes like issuing goods for production or picking for a customer delivery. It uses the same condition technique as pricing.

The goal is to define a strategy for how the system should find batches. A common strategy is FEFO (First-Expired, First-Out), where the system finds all available batches and sorts them to propose the one with the earliest expiration date first.

The configuration involves these building blocks:

  1. Condition Tables: Define the key fields for which a search strategy will be valid. Example keys: Plant / Material, or Plant / Movement Type.
  2. Access Sequences: Defines the search order of condition tables. The system checks them in sequence until it finds a valid strategy record.
  3. Strategy Types: The main container for the strategy. It links to an access sequence and defines general control parameters.
  4. Search Procedures: A sequence of Strategy Types. This defines the overall search logic.
  5. Procedure Assignment: Finally, you assign the Search Procedure to the relevant business process (e.g., to a specific movement type for inventory management, or to a production order type).

2.4 Selection and Sort Rules

Within a batch search strategy, you specify how to select and sort the batches found.

  • Selection Class (CL02 with Class Type 023): You create a special class that contains the characteristics you want to use for selection. In the strategy record (MBC1, VCH1, etc.), you assign this class and specify the required values. For example, to ensure only unrestricted batches are selected, you would use the characteristic

LOBM_ZUSTD and specify the value 'Unrestricted'.

  • Sort Rule (CU70): You create a sort sequence that tells the system in what order to present the selected batches. To achieve FEFO, you would create a sort rule that sorts batches in

ascending order based on the characteristic LOBM_VFDAT (SLED).

Chapter 3: End-to-End Business Processes

Let's see how batch management works in practice across the supply chain.

3.1 Procurement (MM) – Receiving a Batch

When you receive goods from a supplier, a new batch is created in your system.

  • Process:
    1. Create a Purchase Order (ME21N).
    2. Post the Goods Receipt against the PO.
  • SAP GUI: MIGO (Movement Type 101)
  • SAP Fiori App: Post Goods Receipt for Purchasing Document

During the goods receipt, the system will prompt for batch information:

  • Batch Number: If using internal assignment, the system proposes a new number. If external, you enter the supplier's batch number.
  • Date of Production: You must enter this date.
  • SLED Calculation: Based on the Date of Production and the Total shelf life from the material master, the system automatically calculates and proposes the SLED.
  • SLED Check: The system compares the SLED with the current date to see if the Min. remaining shelf life is met. If not, it issues a message.
  • Classification: You will be prompted to enter values for the characteristics defined in the batch class (e.g., Potency, Country of Origin).

3.2 Production (PP) – Consuming and Creating Batches

Batch management is vital in production for both consuming components and creating new batches of finished products.

Goods Issue to a Production Order (Component Consumption)

  • Process: When you need to issue raw materials to a production order, batch determination helps you pick the right ones.
  • SAP GUI: MIGO or COWBHUWE (Movement Type 261)
  • SAP Fiori App: Pick Components for Production Orders

When staging or issuing components, you can trigger batch determination by entering

* in the batch field. The system will then execute the search strategy (e.g., FEFO) and propose the appropriate batches to be consumed.

Goods Receipt from a Production Order (Finished Good Creation)

  • Process: Once the production order is complete, you post a goods receipt for the finished product.
  • SAP GUI: MIGO or MB31 (Movement Type 101)
  • SAP Fiori App: Post Goods Receipt for Production Order

At this point, a new batch is created for the finished product. Similar to the procurement process, you will provide a production date, the system will calculate the SLED, and you will fill in the classification values for the finished good.

3.3 Sales & Distribution (SD) – Shipping a Batch

When creating a delivery for a customer, batch determination ensures you pick and ship the correct batches.

  • Process:
    1. Create a Sales Order (VA01).
    2. Create an Outbound Delivery (VL01N).
  • SAP Fiori App: Create Sales Orders, Manage Outbound Deliveries

During delivery creation or picking, batch determination is triggered automatically. The FEFO strategy is very common here to ensure older products are shipped first, minimizing the risk of expiration.

3.4 Warehouse Management (EWM) – The Physical Link

In a warehouse-managed environment, EWM handles the physical execution. Batch information is seamlessly integrated.

  • Integration: When a batch is created in S/4HANA (ERP), the batch master data is automatically replicated to the EWM system.
  • Batch Determination in EWM: Search strategies can be configured directly in EWM. When a picking warehouse task is created, EWM determines the exact batch to be picked from a specific storage bin, often following FEFO rules defined in the EWM configuration.
  • Status Management: The Unrestricted/Restricted status is also replicated to EWM, preventing the picking of blocked batches.

Chapter 4: Key Tools and Reports

SAP provides powerful tools for managing and analyzing batches.

4.1 The Batch Master Record

This is the central object containing all data for a specific batch.

  • SAP GUI: MSC2N (Change), MSC3N (Display)
  • SAP Fiori App: Manage Batches

Here you can view or change the batch status, SLED, and classification values.

4.2 Batch Information Cockpit (BIC)

This is the most powerful tool for traceability analysis.

  • SAP GUI: BMBC
  • SAP Fiori App: Batch Information Cockpit

With BMBC, you can select a batch and perform:

  • Top-Down Where-Used List: See where this batch was used. For a raw material, this will show all the production orders and finished good batches it went into.
  • Bottom-Up Where-Used List: See where this batch came from. For a finished good, this will show the production order and the specific raw material batches that were consumed.
  • Linked Documents: Instantly navigate to related material documents, inspection lots, and handling units.

4.3 SLED and Availability Reporting

  • SLED List (SAP GUI: MB5M, Fiori App: Shelf Life Expiration Date): This report is essential for proactive management of expiring stock. You can run it to see all batches that will expire within a given timeframe (e.g., in the next 30 days). This allows you to take action, such as prioritizing these batches for sale or flagging them for disposal.
  • Stock Availability (SAP GUI: MMBE, Fiori App: Stock - Single Material): This provides a real-time overview of stock, broken down by batches and their status (Unrestricted, Restricted, Quality Inspection).

Chapter 5: Comprehensive Test Plan

This test plan provides end-to-end scenarios for users and consultants to practice and validate the batch management configuration.

Introduction

  • Objective: To validate the entire batch management process flow, from master data setup to cross-functional execution and traceability.
  • Prerequisites: All necessary configuration from Chapter 2 must be complete. Required master data (Business Partners, Plants, etc.) must exist.

Scenario 1: Master Data Creation and Validation

  • Objective: Ensure a new material can be correctly set up for batch management with SLED and classification.
  • Test Steps:
    1. Using Fiori app Manage Product Master Data, create a new Raw Material (e.g., RM-BATCH-01).
    2. In the General Plant Data view, check the Batch management indicator.
    3. In the Plant Data / Stor. 1 view, enter Total shelf life = 180 days and Min. remaining shelf life = 30 days.
    4. Using transaction CT04, create a new characteristic Z_SUPPLIER_CERT (Character, 20 characters).
    5. Using transaction CL02, create a new batch class CL_RAW_MATERIAL (Type 023) and assign characteristics LOBM_HSDAT and Z_SUPPLIER_CERT.
    6. Return to the Manage Product Master Data app for RM-BATCH-01. Go to the Classification view and assign class CL_RAW_MATERIAL.
    7. Save the material.
  • Expected Result: The material is saved successfully with all batch-relevant data. No errors should occur.

Scenario 2: Procure-to-Pay with SLED Check

  • Objective: Test the creation of a batch during goods receipt and validate the SLED check.
  • Test Steps:
    1. Using Fiori app Create Purchase Order - Advanced (ME21N), create a PO for 100 KG of material RM-BATCH-01.
    2. Launch the Post Goods Receipt for Purchasing Document app (MIGO). Enter the PO number.
    3. On the item detail screen, navigate to the Batch tab.
    4. Enter the Date of Production as a date from 20 days ago.
    5. Press Enter. The system should calculate the SLED as (Production Date + 180 days).
    6. In the Classification section, enter a value for the Z_SUPPLIER_CERT characteristic (e.g., CERT-12345).
    7. Post the goods receipt. A new internal batch number should be assigned. Note this number.
    8. Negative Test: Attempt another goods receipt for the same PO. This time, enter a Date of Production that is 160 days ago.
  • Expected Result:
    • The first goods receipt posts successfully.
    • For the second (negative test), the system should issue a warning or error message stating that the minimum remaining shelf life of 30 days is not met (180 total - 160 elapsed = 20 days remaining < 30). The posting should be blocked if configured as an error.

Scenario 3: Plan-to-Produce with Batch Determination (FEFO)

  • Objective: Validate automatic batch determination (FEFO) for component consumption and the creation of a finished good batch.
  • Prerequisites: Create a Finished Good material (FG-BATCH-01) that is also batch-managed and has RM-BATCH-01 as a component in its Bill of Materials (BOM). Have at least two different batches of RM-BATCH-01 in stock with different SLEDs.
  • Test Steps:
    1. Using Fiori app Create Production Order (CO01), create an order for 10 units of FG-BATCH-01. Release the order.
    2. Launch the Post Goods Issue for Production Order app (MIGO, Mvt 261).
    3. Enter the production order number. For the component RM-BATCH-01, enter * in the Batch field and press Enter.
    4. The system should trigger batch determination and propose the batch of RM-BATCH-01 with the oldest SLED.
    5. Post the goods issue.
    6. Once complete, launch the Post Goods Receipt for Production Order app (MIGO, Mvt 101).
    7. Post the receipt for FG-BATCH-01. A new batch will be created.
  • Expected Result: Batch determination correctly proposes the oldest batch of the raw material. A new, unique batch is successfully created for the finished good.

Scenario 4: Order-to-Cash with Batch Determination

  • Objective: Validate batch determination during the outbound delivery process.
  • Prerequisites: Have stock of the new FG-BATCH-01 batch.
  • Test Steps:
    1. Using Fiori app Create Sales Order (VA01), create an order for 5 units of FG-BATCH-01.
    2. Using Fiori app Manage Outbound Deliveries (VL01N), create a delivery for the sales order.
    3. In the delivery item details picking tab, click the "Batch split" or "Batch determination" button.
    4. The system should automatically find and assign the available batch of FG-BATCH-01.
    5. Enter the picked quantity, post the goods issue, and proceed with billing.
  • Expected Result: The system correctly finds and allocates the batch stock to the outbound delivery. The goods issue reduces the stock of that specific batch.

Scenario 5: Quality Inspection and Status Change

  • Objective: Test the integration with QM and the impact of a usage decision on the batch status.
  • Prerequisites: Activate QM for material RM-BATCH-01 with an inspection type for goods receipt.
  • Test Steps:
    1. Perform a new goods receipt for RM-BATCH-01.
    2. Note that the stock goes into Quality Inspection status and an inspection lot is created.
    3. Using Fiori app Record Usage Decision (QA32), find the inspection lot.
    4. Make the usage decision. In the Inspection lot stock tab, specify that the quantity should move to "Restricted-use stock".
    5. Save the usage decision.
    6. Display the batch master using the Manage Batches app (MSC3N).
  • Expected Result: An inspection lot is created upon GR. After the usage decision, the batch master status should change from "Unrestricted" to "Restricted". The physical stock should now be in the "Restricted" stock type.

Scenario 6: End-to-End Traceability Test

  • Objective: Use the Batch Information Cockpit to perform a full traceability analysis.
  • Test Steps:
    1. Launch the Batch Information Cockpit app (BMBC).
    2. Enter the batch number of the finished good FG-BATCH-01 created in Scenario 3.
    3. Execute the analysis.
    4. Click the Bottom-up analysis button.
    5. Now, enter the batch number of the raw material RM-BATCH-01 that was consumed.
    6. Click the Top-down analysis button.
  • Expected Result:
    • The bottom-up analysis for the finished good should show the production order it came from and, one level deeper, the specific batch of RM-BATCH-01 that was consumed.
    • The top-down analysis for the raw material should show the production order it was consumed in, and the specific FG-BATCH-01 batch that was produced. The chain should be complete and accurate.

entry.title: The Ultimate Guide to SAP S/4HANA Master Data Management
entry.content:
The Ultimate Guide to SAP S/4HANA Master Data Management

Guide Version: 1.0

Applicable To: SAP S/4HANA 2020 and higher

  • Welcome to your definitive guide for understanding, creating, and managing master data in SAP S/4HANA. This document is designed for all users—from beginners and end-users to key users and seasoned consultants. We will transform the fundamental procedures into a cohesive, end-to-end process flow, focusing on modern SAP Fiori applications and standard best practices.

Part 1: The Comprehensive Master Data Guide

Chapter 1: Introduction to Master Data in SAP S/4HANA

What is Master Data? Why is it Crucial? 🤔

  • Think of your business as a complex story. To tell this story, you need main characters (your customers, suppliers), key objects (the products you sell, the materials you buy), and locations (your plants, warehouses). Master data is the permanent, core information that defines these characters and objects.
  • Unlike transactional data (like a sales order or an invoice), which is dynamic and records a specific event, master data is relatively static. It's the "who, what, and where" of your business operations.
  • Why is it so important?
  • Consistency: It ensures that every department refers to the same customer, product, or supplier in the same way.
  • Efficiency: It eliminates the need to re-enter the same information for every transaction. You create it once and use it everywhere.
  • Accuracy: Clean master data leads to accurate reporting, reliable planning, and smooth business processes. Garbage in, garbage out!

Key Master Data Objects in S/4HANA

  • This guide will focus on several critical master data objects:
  • Business Partner (BP): The unified record for all your customers, suppliers, employees, and contacts.
  • Material Master: The central repository for all information on materials you procure, produce, store, and sell.
  • Purchasing & Sales Records: Data that defines relationships, like Scheduling Agreements and Pricing Conditions.
  • Service & Maintenance Data: Objects like Task Lists and Warranties that support your service operations.
  • Document Info Record (DIR): A record to manage unstructured documents like technical drawings or specifications.

The SAP Fiori Launchpad: Your Modern Gateway

  • In SAP S/4HANA, the primary user interface is the SAP Fiori Launchpad. It's a role-based, personalized, and simplified user experience. Instead of complex menu paths, you'll use "apps" (tiles) to perform your tasks. We will prioritize Fiori apps throughout this guide. When a modern app isn't available, we will refer to the classic SAP GUI, which can also be accessed from the Fiori Launchpad.

Chapter 2: The Business Partner (BP) - A Single Source of Truth

  • In older SAP systems, you created customers and vendors separately. S/4HANA simplifies this with the Business Partner (BP) model. A single BP record can hold all the roles a real-world entity plays in relation to your company.

Concept: BP Roles

  • A single company, "Global Tech Inc.," can be your customer and your supplier. In the BP model, you create one Business Partner record for Global Tech and then extend it with different BP Roles:
  • General Role (000000): Contains basic data like name, address, and communication details. This is the foundation.
  • FI Customer (FLCU00): Contains company-code-specific data for accounting, like reconciliation accounts and payment terms.
  • Customer (FLCU01): Contains sales-area-specific data, like shipping conditions and sales office details.
  • FI Vendor (FLVN00): The accounting view for a supplier.
  • Supplier (FLVN01): The purchasing-organization view for a supplier.

How-To: Create a Business Partner

  • Let's create a new business partner who will be both a customer and a supplier.
  • Fiori App: Manage Business Partner Master Data
  1. Launch the App: Open the Manage Business Partner Master Data app from your Fiori Launchpad.
  2. Create a New BP: Click the Create button and select Organization.
  3. Create in BP Role (General):
    • Start by creating the BP in the general role. This is often the default.
    • BP Grouping: Choose a grouping. This determines the number range (internal or external). Let's use an internal one.
    • Basic Data: Enter the Company Name, Search Term, and full Address details.
    • Click Save. The system will assign a Business Partner number. Note this number down!
  4. Extend to Customer Role:
    • With your new BP open, switch to edit mode.
    • In the "Create in BP Role" dropdown, select Customer (FLCU01) and click Create.
    • A new section for Sales and Distribution will appear. Enter the Sales Organization, Distribution Channel, and Division.
    • Navigate to the Shipping tab and enter the Delivering Plant and Shipping Conditions.
    • Navigate to the Billing tab and set the Tax Classification (e.g., 1 for taxable).
    • Click Save.
  5. Extend to FI Customer Role:
    • While still in edit mode, select the role FI Customer (FLCU00).
    • A new section for Company Code will appear. Click Add.
    • Enter your Company Code and the Reconciliation Account.
    • Click Save.
  6. Extend to Supplier Role:
    • Now, let's make this BP a supplier. In the "Create in BP Role" dropdown, select Supplier (FLVN01).
    • A Purchasing section will appear. Enter the Purchasing Organization.
    • On the Partner Functions tab, add the necessary details.
    • Click Save.
  7. Extend to FI Vendor Role:
    • Finally, select role FI Vendor (FLVN00).
    • Go to the Company Code section, add your company code, and enter the Reconciliation Account for payables.
    • Click Save.
  • Result: You now have a single Business Partner number that represents a company that can buy from you and sell to you, with all the necessary data maintained in one central place.

Chapter 3: The Material Master - The Heart of Logistics

  • The material master is arguably the most complex and critical master data object in logistics. It holds all the information required to manage a material. This data is segregated into different views, each relevant to a specific business function (e.g., Sales, Purchasing, Accounting).

Key Concept: Material Types

  • The Material Type is a crucial classification that controls a material's behavior in the system. Examples include:
  • ROH (Raw Materials): Purchased externally, used in production.
  • HALB (Semi-finished Goods): Produced in-house, used to make other products.
  • FERT (Finished Goods): Produced in-house, sold to customers.
  • HAWA (Trading Goods): Purchased externally and sold directly to customers.
  • LEIH (Returnable Packaging): Materials like pallets or containers that are loaned to customers and returned111.
  • DIEN (Services): Non-physical materials used for procurement or sales of services.

How-To 1: Create a Returnable Packaging Material (LEIH)

  • This process is based on document 155_BPD_73_EN_TR. We'll create a material master for a returnable pallet.
  • SAP GUI Transaction: MM01 (Create Material)
  • (While there are Fiori apps like Manage Product Master Data, MM01 remains powerful and widely used for initial creation).
  1. Initial Screen:
    • Material: Leave blank for internal number assignment2.
    • Industry sector: Select M - Mechanical engineering3.
    • Material Type: Select LEIH - Returnable packaging4.
    • Press Enter.
  2. Select View(s):
    • This is a critical step where you choose which business functions will use this material.
    • Select the following views5:
      • Basic Data 1 & 2
      • Sales: Sales Org. Data 1 & 2
      • Sales: General/Plant Data
      • Purchasing
      • MRP 1, 2, 3
      • General Plant Data / Storage 1 & 2
      • Warehouse Management 1
      • Accounting 1 & 2
    • Click Enter or the checkmark.
  3. Organizational Levels:
    • The system now asks where these views are valid.
    • Enter your Plant (e.g., 1000), Sales Org. (e.g., 1000), and Distr. Channel (e.g., 10)6.
    • Click Enter.
  4. Populate the Views:
    • Basic Data 1:
      • Description: "Standard Wooden Pallet"
      • Base Unit of Measure: "EA" (Each) 7
      • Division: "10" (Cross-division) 8
      • GenItemCatGroup: LEIH (Returnable packaging) 9
      • Gross Weight / Net Weight: Enter the physical weight.
    • Sales: Sales Org. 1:
      • Delivering Plant: "1000" 10
      • Tax classification: Set the appropriate tax category11.
    • Sales: Sales Org. 2:
      • Item category group: LEIH will be defaulted from Basic Data, but ensure it's correct. A specific one like
  • YB02 might be used for returnable packaging deliveries12.
    • Sales: General/Plant:
      • Availability check: Y2 (Individual requirements) 13
      • Trans. Grp: 0001 (e.g., On pallets) 14
      • LoadingGrp: 0001 (e.g., Crane) 15
    • Purchasing:
      • Purchasing group: Enter the responsible purchasing group (e.g., 001)16.
    • MRP 1:
      • MRP type: ND (No planning), as you typically don't plan for these items via MRP17.
    • Accounting 1:
      • Valuation Class: 3050 (Returnable Packaging) or as defined by your configuration18.
      • Price control: S (Standard price)19.
      • Standard price: Enter the value of one pallet.
  1. Save the Material:
    • Continue pressing Enter through the remaining views. The system will prompt you to save when you've reached the last selected view. Click
  • Yes20.
  • Result: A new material master for returnable packaging has been created.

How-To 2: Extend a Material to New Organizational Levels

  • This process is based on 155_BPD_63_EN_TR. Once a material exists, you often need to make it available in other locations (plants, warehouses) or sell it through different sales channels.
  • Use Case: Your company has created the "Standard Wooden Pallet" for Plant 1000. Now, Plant 1100 also needs to use it.
  • SAP GUI Transaction: MM01 (Create Material) - Yes, you use Create again, but by referencing an existing material, it becomes an extension process.
  1. Initial Screen:
    • Material: Enter the material number of your "Standard Wooden Pallet".
    • Copy from... Material: Enter the same material number again21. This tells the system you are extending, not creating from scratch.
    • Press Enter.
  2. Select View(s):
    • The system will show you the views that have already been created.
    • Select the plant-dependent views you need to create for the new plant. For example:
      • Purchasing
      • MRP 1, 2, 3, 4
      • General Plant Data / Storage 1, 2
      • Accounting 1, 2
      • Costing 1, 2
    • Click Enter.
  3. Organizational Levels:
    • Plant: Enter the new plant, 110022.
    • Copy from... Plant: Enter the original plant, 100023. This will copy all the existing plant-specific data as a template, saving you time.
    • Click Enter.
  4. Review and Adjust Data:
    • The system will now walk you through each view you selected for Plant 1100, with the data copied from Plant 1000.
    • You must review and adjust data that is specific to the new plant. For example:
      • MRP 1: The MRP controller might be different for Plant 110024.
      • MRP 2: The Procurement Type could differ. Maybe in Plant 1100, this pallet is transferred from Plant 1000, not purchased.
      • Accounting 1: The Standard price could be different due to transport costs.
  5. Save the Extension:
    • After reviewing all views, the system will prompt you to save. Click Yes.
  • Result: Your material is now active and can be used in transactions for both Plant 1000 and Plant 1100.

Chapter 4: Advanced Material Concepts - Batch Management & Classification

  • Batch management is essential for industries where traceability and shelf-life are critical (e.g., pharmaceuticals, food, chemicals). It allows you to track a specific production lot (a "batch") from goods receipt to final delivery.
  • This process is based on document 155_BPD_62_EN_TR.

Concepts:

  • Batch: A quantity of material produced during a single manufacturing run, possessing uniform characteristics.
  • Classification System: A powerful tool in SAP that lets you assign specific attributes (Characteristics) to objects (like a batch) by grouping them into a Class. For example, you can classify a batch of a chemical with characteristics like 'Potency %', 'Color', and 'Expiration Date'.
  • Batch Search Strategy: A sophisticated method (using the condition technique) to automatically find and propose the right batches during sales, production, or goods issue processes based on specific criteria (e.g., First-Expired-First-Out).

How-To: Set up Batch Determination (FEFO - First Expired, First Out)

  • Step 1: Create Characteristics
  • We need to define the attributes we want to store for our batches. For FEFO, the key characteristic is the expiration date. SAP provides a standard one, but let's see how to create one.
  • Fiori App: Manage Characteristics (or GUI T-Code CT04)
  1. Characteristic Name: Enter YB_SUPPLIER_BATCH 25 and click
  • Create.
  1. Basic Data Tab:
    • Description: "Supplier Batch Number"26.
    • Status: Set to Released.
    • Data Type: Character Format (CHAR)27.
    • Number of Chars: 1528.
  2. Additional Data Tab:
    • This is an optional but powerful step. You can link the characteristic to a table field, so it gets populated automatically.
    • Table Name: MCH1 (Batch Master Table)29.
    • Field Name: LICHA (Supplier Batch Number)30.
  3. Save your characteristic.
  4. Note: For FEFO, we will primarily use the standard SAP characteristic LOBM_VFDAT (Expiration Date), which is pre-configured to work perfectly for this purpose.
  • Step 2: Create a Class
  • Now, we group our characteristics into a class that will be assigned to the material.
  • Fiori App: Manage Classes (or GUI T-Code CL01)
  1. Initial Screen:
    • Class: YB_EXP_DATE_00131.
    • Class type: 023 (for Batches)32. This is crucial.
    • Click Create.
  2. Basic Data Tab:
    • Description: "Batch Class for Expiration Date"33.
    • Status: Released34.
  3. Characteristics Tab:
    • Enter the characteristics you want in this class. For our FEFO scenario, add:
      • LOBM_VFDAT (Expiration date) 35
      • LOBM_RLZ (Remaining Shelf Life) 36
  4. Save your class.
  • Step 3: Assign Class to Material
  • You must now tell the system that materials using this class are subject to batch management.
  1. Go to the Change Material (MM02) transaction.
  2. Select the Classification view.
  3. Assign your class YB_EXP_DATE_001 under the class type 023.
  4. Go to the Purchasing or Plant data / stor. 1 view and check the Batch management indicator.
  5. Save the material.
  • Step 4: Create a Sort Sequence
  • This defines the order in which the found batches should be sorted. For FEFO, we want to sort by expiration date in ascending order.
  • GUI Transaction: CU70
  1. Sort Sequence: Enter YB_EXP_DATE_SORT 37 and click
  • Create.
  1. Description: "Sort by Expiration Date"38.
  2. In the
  • Characteristics section, enter LOBM_VFDAT39.
  1. Ensure the Ascending indicator is checked. This ensures the earliest date comes first.
  2. Save the sort sequence.
  • Step 5: Define the Batch Search Strategy for Sales (SD)
  • This is where we pull everything together.
  • GUI Transaction: VCH1 (Create SD Batch Search Strategy)
  1. Strategy type: Select the appropriate type, for example YB12 (Expiration Date)40. Press
  • Enter.
  1. Key Combination: A dialog box will appear. Choose the level at which you want to define the strategy. "Material" is a common choice. Select it and press
  • Enter41.
  1. Main Screen:
    • Enter your Material number.
    • Set
  • No. batch splits to 99 to allow the system to pick from multiple batches if needed42.
  1. Selection Criteria:
    • Select the line you just created and click the Selection criteria button.
    • Here, you can specify values. For FEFO, we want batches with an expiration date greater than today. You can leave this blank to find all valid batches, as the sort sequence will handle the ordering.
    • Go back.
  2. Sort:
    • Select the line again and click the Sort button.
    • Enter your sort sequence
  • YB_EXP_DATE_SORT43.
    • Go back.
  1. Save the strategy.
  • Result: When you create a sales order delivery for this material, the system will automatically find all available batches, sort them by the expiration date (earliest first), and propose them for picking.

Chapter 5: Procurement & Engineering Master Data

How-To 1: Create a Scheduling Agreement

  • A scheduling agreement is a long-term outline agreement with a supplier for the supply of materials, subject to predetermined conditions. Deliveries are made based on specific delivery schedules. This is based on 155_BPD_72_EN_TR.
  • Fiori App: Manage Scheduling Agreements (or GUI T-Code ME31L)
  1. Initial Screen:
    • Enter the
  • Vendor number, Agreement Type (e.g., LP), Agreement Date, and your Purch.Org/Purch Grp44.
    • Press Enter.
  1. Header Data:
    • Enter the Validity Start and Validity End dates for the agreement.
  2. Item Overview:
    • Material: Enter the material number you are procuring.
    • Target quantity: Enter the total expected quantity over the agreement's lifetime.
    • Net price: Enter the agreed price per unit45.
  3. Save the scheduling agreement. The system will provide a number.
  • Maintain Delivery Schedule
  • GUI Transaction: ME38
  1. Enter your Scheduling Agreement number.
  2. Select the item line and click the Delivery schedule button.
  3. Enter the dates and the corresponding quantities you want the supplier to deliver46.
  4. Save the schedule. This schedule can now be transmitted to the supplier.

How-To 2: Create a Document Info Record (DIR)

  • DIRs are used to manage documents like CAD drawings, specifications, or images and link them to SAP objects like materials. This is based on 155_BPD_71_EN_TR.
  • Fiori App: Manage Documents (or GUI T-Code CV01N)
  1. Initial Screen:
    • Document Type: Choose a type, e.g., YBO for Office Documents47. The type controls the document's behavior.
    • Press Enter. The system will assign a number internally.
  2. Basic Data:
    • Description: Enter a clear description, e.g., "Technical Drawing for Pump P-100"48.
  3. Create Original:
    • At the bottom, click Create Original.
    • Browse for the file on your computer (e.g., a PDF or DOCX file) and upload it49.
  4. Object Links:
    • Navigate to the Object Links tab.
    • Here, you can link this DIR to other SAP objects. Enter MARA (Material Master table) and then your material number.
  5. Save the DIR.
  • Result: Anyone viewing the material master can now see that there is a linked technical drawing and can open it directly from SAP.

Chapter 6: Service and Maintenance Master Data

  • These objects are fundamental to the Plant Maintenance (PM) and Customer Service (CS) modules.

How-To 1: Create a Master Warranty

  • This defines the terms of a warranty that can be assigned to equipment or sold to customers. This is based on 155_BPD_69_EN_TR.
  • GUI Transaction: BGM1 (Create Master Warranty)
  1. Leave the
  • Master Warranty number blank for internal assignment50. Press
  • Enter.
  1. Description: "Standard 12-Month Guarantee"51.
  2. Warranty type: 1 (Customer warranty)52.
  3. Services Tab: Enter text describing the warranty terms53.
  4. Counters Tab: This defines the warranty's duration.
    • Click Create counter.
    • WarrCounter: WARRANTY_PERIOD (Time-based)54.
    • Warr. Counter value: 1255.
    • Unit: MON (Months).
  5. Save the master warranty.

How-To 2: Create a General Task List

  • A task list is a template that contains a sequence of operations needed to perform a maintenance or service task. This avoids having to enter the same steps every time you create a work order. This is based on 155_BPD_66_EN_TR.
  • Fiori App: Manage Task Lists (or GUI T-Code IA05)
  1. Press Enter on the initial screen to get a group number.
  2. Header Details:
    • Description: "Annual Pump Inspection"56.
    • Planning plant: 100057.
